welcome.branding: In partnership with the inspiring spirit of the University of Malaya

slide1.title: Welcome, Dear Parent! üíù
slide1.subtitle: We're So Glad You're Here
slide1.description: Parenting through puberty can feel overwhelming, but you don't have to navigate it alone. This app is designed with love to support YOU in supporting your child through one of life's most significant transitions. Together, we'll make this journey smoother for your whole family.

slide2.title: Understanding Your Role
slide2.subtitle: You're Your Child's Most Important Guide
slide2.description: Your child needs your wisdom, patience, and unconditional support more than ever. This app helps you understand what they're experiencing physically and emotionally, so you can provide the guidance they need while respecting their growing independence and privacy.

slide3.title: What This App Offers
slide3.subtitle: Everything You Need in One Place
slide3.feature1: Expert parenting guidance on communication and emotional support
slide3.feature2: Educational games and activities for your child
slide3.feature3: Age-appropriate information about physical and emotional changes
slide3.feature4: AI-powered assistant to answer your parenting questions
slide3.feature5: Private diary space for your child to process their feelings

slide4.title: Your Privacy & Safety Matter
slide4.subtitle: We Take Your Trust Seriously
slide4.point1: All data stays on your device - nothing is sent to external servers
slide4.point2: No tracking, no analytics, no third-party access to your information
slide4.point3: The diary feature is completely private - only your child can access their entries
slide4.point4: This is a safe, judgment-free space designed with child safety and family privacy as top priorities
slide4.acceptPrivacy: I understand and accept the privacy policy

aiChat.title: Parent Assistant
aiChat.subtitle: Ask me anything about puberty in English, ÿßŸÑÿπÿ±ÿ®Ÿäÿ©, or Bahasa Melayu. I'll reply with practical steps you can try today.
aiChat.greeting: Hello! I'm your multilingual puberty support guide. I can chat in English, Arabic, or Bahasa Melayu‚Äîwhatever feels kindest for you. Tell me what's happening and I'll share gentle scripts, daily ideas, and reminders for looking after yourself, too. What would you like help with?
aiChat.suggestedTitle: You can get started quickly with:

suggestions.q1: How can I explain puberty stages gently?
suggestions.q2: What helps when my child feels overwhelmed?
suggestions.q3: How do we build a daily self-care routine?
suggestions.q4: How can I encourage healthy sleep habits?
suggestions.q5: What should I say about periods and body changes?
suggestions.q6: How do I set respectful rules around devices?

diary.title: Feelings diary

response.puberty:
Great question! Try these steps:
‚Ä¢ Choose relaxed everyday moments‚Äîcar rides, walks, shared chores‚Äîto mention changes you've noticed.
‚Ä¢ Share small facts often instead of one big "talk" so information feels normal.
‚Ä¢ Invite questions by saying, "You can ask me anything, even if it feels awkward."
‚Ä¢ Keep trusted books or articles handy so your child can explore privately and return when they're ready.
‚Ä¢ Reassure them every body grows at its own pace and you are beside them all the way.
response.emotions:
Emotional waves are part of puberty. Try this:
‚Ä¢ Validate feelings first ("I can see this feels really tough").
‚Ä¢ Create a calming toolkit together‚Äîbreathing, stretching, drawing, favourite songs.
‚Ä¢ Encourage them to name emotions and rate how strong they feel.
‚Ä¢ End the day with a short "feelings check" so they know big emotions are welcome at home.
‚Ä¢ If emotions feel overwhelming for both of you, pause the chat and revisit when everyone is calmer.
response.communication:
Strong communication grows through routine.
‚Ä¢ Schedule weekly check-ins and let your child choose the activity.
‚Ä¢ Use openers like, "What was a win and a wobble today?"
‚Ä¢ Reflect back what you hear and thank them for sharing.
‚Ä¢ If conversations heat up, agree to pause, breathe, and continue later‚Äîrespect is more important than winning.
‚Ä¢ Share your own feelings occasionally so they know it's safe to be honest.
response.social:
Friendships can feel stormy right now.
‚Ä¢ Discuss what healthy friendship behaviours look like‚Äîkind words, listening, respecting boundaries.
‚Ä¢ Role-play how to respond to peer pressure so they feel ready.
‚Ä¢ Encourage clubs or teams that match their interests to widen their circle.
‚Ä¢ Remind them that changing friendships are normal and never reflect their worth.
‚Ä¢ Celebrate acts of kindness they show to others to build confidence.
response.privacy:
We built this app with family privacy at heart.
‚Ä¢ Diary entries stay on this device‚Äîno personal data leaves your home.
‚Ä¢ There are no trackers or ads hidden anywhere.
‚Ä¢ Encourage your child to use the diary as a private space to process feelings.
‚Ä¢ Set shared agreements about when, if ever, you'll review entries together.
‚Ä¢ Revisit privacy promises regularly so trust stays strong.
response.activities:
Learning sticks when it's playful.
‚Ä¢ Explore the Games section together and talk about what you both notice.
‚Ä¢ Memory matches build body knowledge, quizzes boost confidence, and emotion games open honest chats.
‚Ä¢ Ask which activity felt most helpful and why.
‚Ä¢ Use their answer as a bridge to keep the conversation going offline.
‚Ä¢ Celebrate participation‚Äînot perfection‚Äîto keep things fun.
response.hygiene:
Help your child build a simple hygiene rhythm.
‚Ä¢ Shower daily or after sports, use deodorant, and change into clean clothes.
‚Ä¢ Care for skin and hair with products that match their needs.
‚Ä¢ Turn it into teamwork: create a checklist and stick it in the bathroom.
‚Ä¢ Practice together the first few times, then cheer on their independence.
‚Ä¢ Praise effort rather than perfection so confidence can grow.
response.nutrition:
Bodies need steady fuel right now.
‚Ä¢ Offer balanced meals‚Äîcolourful fruits and veggies, proteins, whole grains, and plenty of water.
‚Ä¢ Invite your child to plan or cook one meal a week.
‚Ä¢ Keep quick, healthy snacks ready for sudden hunger.
‚Ä¢ Talk about listening to hunger and fullness cues.
‚Ä¢ Share how nourishing foods keep energy and mood steady during growth spurts.
response.sleep:
Hormonal shifts can delay sleepiness.
‚Ä¢ Dim lights an hour before bed and switch to calming activities.
‚Ä¢ Keep wake-up times steady, even on weekends.
‚Ä¢ Offer quiet bonding moments‚Äîstretching, gentle chat, or reading together.
‚Ä¢ If worries keep them awake, jot them in a notebook to revisit tomorrow.
‚Ä¢ Model your own wind-down routine so they see rest as a priority.
response.boundaries:
Talk openly about personal boundaries.
‚Ä¢ Cover body privacy, emotional space, and respecting others' limits.
‚Ä¢ Model asking for consent ("Can I give you a hug?").
‚Ä¢ Practise scripts for saying no kindly but firmly.
‚Ä¢ Celebrate when they speak up for themselves or for friends.
‚Ä¢ Remind them that clear boundaries build healthier, safer relationships.
response.digital:
Create a family media plan together.
‚Ä¢ Agree on screen-free zones‚Äîmealtimes and bedrooms at night are great places to start.
‚Ä¢ Discuss how to handle friend requests, DMs, or surprising content.
‚Ä¢ Teach them to pause before posting and to talk to you if something feels wrong.
‚Ä¢ Promise they won't be in trouble for sharing unsafe online moments.
‚Ä¢ Review the plan regularly as their needs and maturity grow.
response.menstruation:
Approach periods with calm confidence.
‚Ä¢ Explain the basics‚Äîcycle length varies, cramps are common, and supplies exist for every body.
‚Ä¢ Show how to track cycles on paper or in a trusted app.
‚Ä¢ Pack a small school kit with pads, liners, and spare underwear.
‚Ä¢ Discuss pain relief strategies‚Äîheat packs, stretching, doctor visits if needed.
‚Ä¢ Remind them periods are a healthy sign of growth, never something to hide.
response.default: I'm here to help with anything related to puberty, wellbeing, and family communication. Ask about hygiene routines, period support, emotional health, friendships, school stress, faith considerations, or keeping conversations flowing in multiple languages. Let's tackle it together‚Äîwhat's on your mind?

intro.title: How can I help you today?
intro.description: Click on a topic to get instant answers

aiChatWidget.tip: Remember, every child is different. Trust your instincts and don't hesitate to consult healthcare professionals when needed.

communication.question: How do I start talking about puberty?
communication.answer: Start early and keep conversations casual. Use everyday moments like TV shows or books to bring up topics. Be honest, use correct terms, and let them know you're always available to talk. Create a safe space where questions are welcome.

emotions.question: How do I handle mood swings?
emotions.answer: Mood swings are normal during puberty due to hormonal changes. Be patient, validate their feelings, and help them understand this is temporary. Encourage healthy outlets like exercise, hobbies, or talking. Set boundaries but remain understanding.

physical.question: What physical changes should I explain?
physical.answer: Explain growth spurts, body shape changes, skin changes (acne), body odor, and hair growth. Be gender-specific when needed. Emphasize that everyone develops at different rates and there's no "normal" timeline. Use age-appropriate language.

hygiene.question: How do I teach personal hygiene?
hygiene.answer: Make hygiene routines fun and routine. Teach daily showering, deodorant use, dental care, and period care (for girls). Use positive reinforcement, not shame. Lead by example and make supplies easily accessible.

confidence.question: How can I build their confidence?
confidence.answer: Praise effort, not just results. Encourage their interests and hobbies. Help them set achievable goals. Teach them that their worth isn't tied to appearance. Be a positive role model and celebrate small wins together.

support.question: When should I seek professional help?
support.answer: Seek help if you notice: persistent sadness or anxiety, withdrawal from activities, significant weight changes, sleep problems, or talk of self-harm. Trust your instincts - it's always okay to consult a pediatrician or counselor.

emotions.title: Feelings Game
emotions.instructions: Tap the emotion that matches the emoji!

parentGuide.title: Comprehensive Parent Guide
parentGuide.subtitle: Evidence-based advice to help you support your child through puberty üíô

startEarly.title: Start Conversations Early
startEarly.description: Don't wait for 'the talk' - make puberty an ongoing conversation
startEarly.tip1: Begin age-appropriate discussions around age 8-9, before changes start
startEarly.tip2: Use everyday moments as teaching opportunities (TV shows, books, observations)
startEarly.tip3: Keep conversations casual and normalize the topic - avoid making it feel like a big deal
startEarly.tip4: Let your child lead with questions and follow their curiosity

listening.title: Practice Active Listening
listening.description: Truly hearing your child builds trust and openness
listening.tip1: Put away phones and give undivided attention when they want to talk
listening.tip2: Don't interrupt or rush to fix problems - sometimes they just need to be heard
listening.tip3: Reflect back what you hear: 'It sounds like you're feeling...'
listening.tip4: Avoid judgment or dismissing their concerns, even if they seem small to you

openness.title: Create a Judgment-Free Zone
openness.description: Make it safe for your child to share anything with you
openness.tip1: Stay calm when they share difficult things - your reaction determines if they'll share again
openness.tip2: Share age-appropriate stories from your own puberty to show understanding
openness.tip3: Use correct anatomical terms - it removes shame and teaches proper language
openness.tip4: Reassure them that no question is too embarrassing or stupid to ask

moodSwings.title: Understanding Mood Swings
moodSwings.description: Hormonal changes cause real emotional turbulence - it's not just attitude
moodSwings.tip1: Recognize that mood swings are caused by biology, not intentional bad behavior
moodSwings.tip2: Don't take emotional outbursts personally - give space but stay available
moodSwings.tip3: Help them identify emotions: 'You seem frustrated' rather than 'Why are you so angry?'
moodSwings.tip4: Teach coping strategies: deep breathing, physical activity, journaling, or talking

confidence.title: Building Self-Confidence
confidence.description: Puberty can shake self-esteem - your support is crucial
confidence.tip1: Focus on effort and character traits, not just appearance or achievements
confidence.tip2: Point out their strengths regularly, especially in areas they might not notice
confidence.tip3: Model positive self-talk and body acceptance in your own life
confidence.tip4: Help them set realistic goals and celebrate small wins along the way

mentalHealth.title: Watch for Mental Health Concerns
mentalHealth.description: Know when normal mood changes cross into something more serious
mentalHealth.tip1: Persistent sadness lasting more than 2 weeks may indicate depression - seek help
mentalHealth.tip2: Watch for changes in sleep, appetite, grades, or withdrawal from activities they loved
mentalHealth.tip3: Take any mention of self-harm or suicidal thoughts extremely seriously - get immediate help
mentalHealth.tip4: There's no shame in professional help - therapists can provide tools you can't

bodyChanges.title: Explaining Physical Changes
bodyChanges.description: Help your child understand what's happening to their body
bodyChanges.tip1: Explain that everyone develops at different rates - there's no 'normal' timeline
bodyChanges.tip2: Discuss changes before they happen when possible - preparation reduces anxiety
bodyChanges.tip3: Be matter-of-fact about topics like periods, erections, and body hair
bodyChanges.tip4: Reassure them that awkward feelings about their changing body are temporary

hygiene.title: Teaching Proper Hygiene
hygiene.description: New hygiene needs arise during puberty
hygiene.tip1: Provide necessary products without fuss: deodorant, shampoo, menstrual supplies, etc.
hygiene.tip2: Teach daily showering, especially after sports or physical activity
hygiene.tip3: Discuss acne care gently - don't make them feel self-conscious
hygiene.tip4: Make hygiene supplies easily accessible in their bathroom space

health.title: Promoting Healthy Habits
health.description: Puberty is the perfect time to establish lifelong healthy behaviors
health.tip1: Ensure 8-10 hours of sleep nightly - teens need more sleep than you might think
health.tip2: Stock healthy snacks - growing bodies need good fuel frequently
health.tip3: Encourage regular physical activity they enjoy, not just organized sports
health.tip4: Model healthy habits yourself - they learn more from what you do than what you say

friendships.title: Navigating Changing Friendships
friendships.description: Social relationships become more complex during puberty
friendships.tip1: Validate that friendship changes and losses are painful and normal
friendships.tip2: Help them distinguish between healthy and unhealthy friendships
friendships.tip3: Resist the urge to fix friend problems - guide them to solve issues themselves
friendships.tip4: Keep lines of communication open about who they're spending time with

peerPressure.title: Handling Peer Pressure
peerPressure.description: Equip your child with tools to resist negative influences
peerPressure.tip1: Role-play scenarios so they practice saying 'no' before facing real pressure
peerPressure.tip2: Give them an 'out': Let them blame you ('My parents will kill me')
peerPressure.tip3: Discuss the difference between fitting in and changing who they are
peerPressure.tip4: Build confidence in their own values and decision-making abilities

boundaries.title: Teaching Personal Boundaries
boundaries.description: Help your child understand and communicate boundaries
boundaries.tip1: Teach them that their body is theirs - they control who touches it and how
boundaries.tip2: Respect their need for privacy (knocking, not reading diaries, etc.)
boundaries.tip3: Model setting your own boundaries with others
boundaries.tip4: Make it clear they can always tell you if someone makes them uncomfortable

onlineSafety.title: Digital Safety During Puberty
onlineSafety.description: Online risks increase as children become more independent
onlineSafety.tip1: Have open conversations about what they're doing online - avoid just monitoring secretly
onlineSafety.tip2: Discuss the permanence of online posts and the concept of digital footprints
onlineSafety.tip3: Talk about the difference between online personas and reality (including unrealistic bodies)
onlineSafety.tip4: Set clear rules about sharing personal information and photos online

personalSpace.title: Respecting Privacy Needs
personalSpace.description: Balance their need for privacy with your need to keep them safe
personalSpace.tip1: Knock before entering their room - physical privacy builds trust
personalSpace.tip2: Don't read diaries or texts unless you have serious safety concerns
personalSpace.tip3: Create privacy for bathroom and dressing while staying available for questions
personalSpace.tip4: Explain that privacy is a privilege that comes with responsibility and honesty

books.title: Recommended Books & Materials
books.description: Quality resources to supplement your conversations
books.tip1: Age-appropriate books about puberty to leave where your child can read privately
books.tip2: Consider books specific to your child's gender identity and body
books.tip3: Online resources from reputable sources (medical organizations, schools)
books.tip4: This app's interactive games and activities make learning engaging

professional.title: When to Seek Professional Help
professional.description: Sometimes expert guidance is needed - and that's okay
professional.tip1: Pediatrician visits around ages 9-11 for puberty discussions
professional.tip2: Therapist if emotional struggles persist or intensify
professional.tip3: School counselor for social or academic concerns
professional.tip4: Support groups for parents navigating similar challenges

keyPrinciples.title: Core Principles for Parenting Through Puberty

patience.title: Patience is Everything
patience.description: This phase is temporary. Your child will make mistakes, say hurtful things, and test boundaries. Stay steady - your calm consistency is their anchor during this storm.

communication.title: Keep Talking
communication.description: Even when they seem uninterested or push you away, keep showing up. Brief check-ins, notes, texts - find ways to stay connected that work for them.

safety.title: Safety First, Always
safety.description: Trust is important, but so is safety. It's okay to monitor, ask questions, and set boundaries. Being the 'cool parent' is less important than being the protective one.

support.title: Unconditional Love
support.description: No matter how challenging this phase gets, remind your child regularly that your love is unwavering. They need to know they can't lose your love by growing up.

emergency.title: When to Seek Immediate Help
emergency.description: If your child exhibits any of these signs, don't hesitate - get professional help immediately:
emergency.point1: Any mention of self-harm, suicide, or hurting others
emergency.point2: Sudden, dramatic personality changes or complete withdrawal
emergency.point3: Signs of abuse (physical marks, extreme fear, inappropriate sexual knowledge)

header.title: Parent Guide & Parenting Tips
header.subtitle: Expert advice for parents and helpful tips for your child

communication.title: Handling Difficult Conversations
communication.description: When your child asks uncomfortable questions or brings up sensitive topics
tips: Stay calm and don't show shock or embarrassment - your reaction sets the tone
It's okay to say "I need a moment to think" rather than giving a rushed answer
Use age-appropriate language - be honest but don't overwhelm with details
If you don't know something, say so and offer to find out together
Create a safe space where no question is "silly" or "wrong"
Follow up later to see if they have more questions

communication.title: Cultural Sensitivity in Conversations
communication.description: Respecting cultural and religious values while providing accurate information
tips: Acknowledge and respect your family's cultural and religious values
Find ways to discuss puberty that align with your beliefs
Use culturally appropriate examples and language
Connect with community leaders or trusted advisors if needed
Balance cultural values with scientific accuracy
Remember: every family's approach is valid

emotional.title: When Your Child Rejects Your Help
emotional.description: What to do when your child pushes you away or says they don't need help
tips: Don't take it personally - independence is a normal part of development
Stay available without being pushy - let them know you're there when ready
Respect their need for space while maintaining boundaries
Find indirect ways to support (leave helpful resources, check in casually)
Connect them with other trusted adults (aunt, teacher, counselor)
Remember: pushing away is often a sign of struggling, not rejection of you

emotional.title: Supporting Anxious or Stressed Children
emotional.description: Helping your child manage anxiety and stress during puberty
tips: Recognize that puberty itself can be stressful - validate their feelings
Teach simple coping strategies: deep breathing, counting, grounding techniques
Help them identify triggers and create a plan for managing them
Encourage healthy outlets: exercise, art, music, journaling
Model healthy stress management in your own life
Seek professional help if anxiety interferes with daily life

physical.title: Preparing for Your Child's First Period
physical.description: Practical guidance for when your daughter starts menstruating
tips: Have period supplies ready before it starts (pads, tampons, period underwear)
Create a "period kit" for school with supplies and a change of clothes
Normalize periods - talk about them as a natural, healthy process
Teach them how to track their cycle and what to expect
Discuss period pain management options (heat, gentle exercise, pain relief)
Reassure them that irregular periods in the first year are completely normal

physical.title: Supporting Positive Body Image
physical.description: Helping your child develop a healthy relationship with their changing body
tips: Avoid negative comments about your own body or others' bodies
Focus on what bodies can DO, not just how they look
Celebrate diversity - all body shapes and sizes are normal
Limit exposure to unrealistic media images when possible
Encourage activities that make them feel strong and capable
Address body-shaming comments from others immediately

social.title: Navigating First Relationships
social.description: Supporting your child through their first crushes and relationships
tips: Start conversations about healthy relationships early, before dating begins
Discuss consent, respect, and boundaries in age-appropriate ways
Set clear rules about dating that match your family values
Keep communication open - ask about their friends and interests
Help them recognize red flags in relationships
Be a safe person they can talk to about relationship concerns

social.title: Social Media and Peer Influence
social.description: Helping your child navigate social media and online peer pressure
tips: Set clear rules about social media use and privacy settings
Have regular conversations about what they see online
Teach critical thinking about online content and influencers
Monitor their online activity while respecting growing independence
Discuss the difference between online personas and real life
Create tech-free times and spaces for family connection

physical.title: Stay Active
physical.description: Regular exercise helps your body develop healthily and boosts your mood
tips: Aim for at least 60 minutes of activity each day
Try different sports to find what you enjoy
Walking, dancing, and playing with friends all count!
Exercise helps with stress and sleep too

physical.title: Healthy Eating
physical.description: Your growing body needs good nutrition to support all the changes
tips: Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables every day
Drink lots of water - aim for 6-8 glasses daily
Don't skip breakfast - it gives you energy for the day
Limit sugary snacks and drinks

physical.title: Get Enough Sleep
physical.description: Sleep is when your body grows and repairs itself
tips: Teenagers need 8-10 hours of sleep each night
Try to go to bed at the same time every night
Avoid screens 30 minutes before bedtime
Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet

physical.title: Managing Discomfort
physical.description: Some changes might cause temporary discomfort
tips: For growing pains, try gentle stretching
A warm bath can help with muscle aches
Talk to an adult if pain persists or worries you
Remember: most discomfort is temporary

emotional.title: Understanding Your Feelings
emotional.description: It's normal to have big emotions during puberty
tips: All feelings are valid - happy, sad, angry, confused
Mood swings are caused by hormones - they're normal
It's okay to cry or feel overwhelmed sometimes
Your feelings will become more stable with time

emotional.title: Managing Stress
emotional.description: Learn healthy ways to cope with stress and anxiety
tips: Try deep breathing: breathe in for 4, hold for 4, out for 4
Talk to someone you trust about your worries
Exercise is a great stress reliever
Take breaks when you feel overwhelmed

emotional.title: Building Self-Confidence
emotional.description: Feeling good about yourself takes practice
tips: Focus on what you like about yourself
Set small, achievable goals and celebrate wins
Don't compare yourself to others - everyone's different
Practice positive self-talk daily

emotional.title: When to Ask for Help
emotional.description: It's important to know when to reach out
tips: If sad feelings last more than 2 weeks
If you have thoughts of hurting yourself
If anxiety stops you from daily activities
Talk to parents, school counselor, or trusted adult

social.title: Friendships
social.description: Relationships become more important during puberty
tips: Real friends accept you for who you are
It's okay if friendships change - you're all growing
Quality is more important than quantity
Be yourself - don't pretend to be someone you're not

social.title: Handling Peer Pressure
social.description: Learn to make your own choices confidently
tips: It's okay to say "no" - real friends will respect that
You don't have to do something just because others do
If something feels wrong, trust your instincts
Find friends who share your values

social.title: Communication
social.description: Express yourself clearly and listen to others
tips: Use "I feel" statements instead of blaming
Listen actively when others speak
It's okay to disagree respectfully
Ask questions if you don't understand

social.title: Personal Boundaries
tips: Your body is yours - you control who touches it
Say "stop" if something makes you uncomfortable
Respect others' boundaries too
Tell a trusted adult if someone crosses your boundaries

hygiene.title: Daily Hygiene
hygiene.description: Keep your body clean and fresh
tips: Shower or bathe daily, especially after exercise
Use soap and shampoo - pay attention to underarms
Wash your face twice daily to prevent acne
Change into clean clothes daily

hygiene.title: Managing Body Odor
tips: Use deodorant or antiperspirant daily
Apply after showering and before bed
Wear breathable fabrics like cotton
Keep extra deodorant in your backpack

hygiene.title: Skin Care
hygiene.description: Take care of your changing skin
tips: Wash your face gently - don't scrub too hard
Use oil-free moisturizer if your skin is dry
Never pop pimples - it can cause scarring
See a doctor if acne bothers you

hygiene.title: Period Care (for those who menstruate)
tips: Change pads/tampons every 4-6 hours
Keep supplies in your bag for emergencies
Track your cycle to know when to expect it
Gentle exercise can help with cramps

emergency.title: Need Immediate Help? üÜò
emergency.description: If you're feeling very upset, scared, or need to talk to someone right away, don't wait:
points: Talk to a parent, guardian, or trusted adult immediately
Contact your school counselor or nurse
Call a helpline in your country (they're free and confidential)
Remember: Asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness! üí™

changes.title: Understanding Your Child's Changes
changes.subtitle: Learn what your child is experiencing physically and emotionally üåü

growth.title: Growth Spurts
growth.description: Children grow at different rates. Growth spurts can be rapid and awkward.

bodyShape.title: Body Shape Changes
bodyShape.description: Body develops new proportions and curves as they mature.

voice.title: Voice Changes
voice.description: Voice may deepen or change in pitch - especially in boys.

skin.title: Skin Changes
skin.description: Acne and oily skin are common. Good hygiene helps manage this.

hair.title: Hair Growth
hair.description: New hair grows in underarms, pubic area, and on face (boys).

odor.title: Body Odor
odor.description: Increased sweating requires daily deodorant use.

mood.title: Mood Swings
mood.description: Hormonal changes cause real emotional volatility - it's biological.

interests.title: New Interests
interests.description: Children develop new hobbies, passions, and interests.

independence.title: Independence
independence.description: They'll want more privacy and independence from family.

relationships.title: Relationships
relationships.description: Friendships and romantic interests become more important.

awareness.title: Self-Awareness
awareness.description: They think more about identity and who they want to become.

confidence.title: Confidence Challenges
confidence.description: Self-esteem often dips during puberty - they need reassurance.

remember.title: Important Reminders for Parents üåà
remember.timing: Timing: Puberty can start ages 8-14. Every child is unique - don't compare!
remember.pace: Pace: Some changes happen quickly, others take years. Be patient.
remember.support: Support: Keep communication open. Your child needs to know you're available for any questions or concerns.

diary.title: Your Child's Feelings Diary
diary.subtitle: A private space for your child to track and express their emotions üìù
diary.description: Track your moods and thoughts during your journey üìù
diary.placeholder: What's on your mind? Share your thoughts, feelings, or what happened today...
diary.listEmpty: No entries yet. Start by adding your first one! üí≠
diary.note: Note: You can export your mood calendar to Google Calendar. Each entry will show your mood for that day.
diary.noEntries: No entries yet. Start by adding your first one! üí≠

tips.title: üí° Diary Tips for Your Child
tips.regular: ‚ú® Write regularly - even just a few sentences helps!
tips.honest: üéØ Be honest about feelings - this is a private space
tips.lookback: üåà Look back at old entries to see growth over time
tips.valid: üí™ Remember: all feelings are valid and normal

confidencePage.title: Confidence, Self-Acceptance & Lifestyle
confidencePage.subtitle: Build healthy habits and boost your confidence one step at a time! üåüüí™

currentFocus.title: Current Focus
currentFocus.subtitle: One habit at a time for better success! üí™

confidencePage.habitLimit: Focus on one habit at a time! Complete your current habit before adding a new one. üí™
confidencePage.habitCompletion: Amazing! You've completed {days} days! You can add a new habit or keep building this one!
confidencePage.availableHabits: Choose a habit to focus on
confidencePage.habitLocked: Complete your current habit (7+ days) to unlock new ones!
confidencePage.chooseHabit: Choose a habit to start your journey!

habits.name: Daily Exercise
habits.description: Move your body for at least 30 minutes

habits.name: Mindful Moment
habits.description: Take 5 minutes to breathe and relax

progress.title: How does this build confidence?
points: Success ‚ûú Completing daily habits proves you can set goals and achieve them
Self-Control ‚ûú Proving to yourself that you can stick to habits builds trust in yourself
Direct Feedback ‚ûú Seeing your progress (streaks, completed days) shows you're reliable
Self-Acceptance ‚ûú When you achieve your goals, you learn to value yourself without needing others' approval

tips.title: Building Confidence Tips üí°
items: One Habit at a Time: Focus on one healthy habit before adding another so you can succeed!
Track Your Progress: Seeing your streak and completed days proves you're capable and reliable.
Celebrate Small Wins: Every day you complete your habit is a victory worth celebrating!
Be Patient: Building confidence takes time. Be kind to yourself on the journey.

game.title: Good / Not Good Activity
game.description: Choose whether each activity feels GOOD or NOT GOOD for your lifestyle and well-being.

feedback.perfect: Perfect! You understand healthy lifestyle choices! üåü
feedback.almost: Great job! Keep learning about healthy habits! üí™

hygienePage.title: Hygiene & Self-Care Routines
hygienePage.subtitle: Build your daily hygiene routine and learn about self-care! Drag on desktop or tap on phones. üßº‚ú®

tips.title: Hygiene Tips üí°
tips.daily: Daily Routine: Establishing a consistent hygiene routine helps you feel clean and confident!
tips.morning: Morning & Evening: Brush your teeth twice a day and wash your face regularly.
tips.hands: After Activities: Wash your hands after playing, before eating, and after using the bathroom.
tips.shower: Shower Regularly: Taking a shower daily helps keep your body clean and fresh.

remember.title: Remember: Every Child is Unique üåà
remember.timing: ‚è∞ Timing: Changes can start ages 8-14 and continue into late teens.
remember.variation: üìè Variation: There's NO single 'normal' - everyone develops differently!
remember.questions: üí¨ Questions? Encourage your child to talk with you, their doctor, or a trusted adult.
remember.health: üè• Health: If something causes pain or worries your child, consult a healthcare provider.

guidance.title: Practical Guidance for Your Child
guidance.subtitle: Help your child learn to handle puberty changes with confidence üí™

bodyImage.title: Positive Body Image Activities
bodyImage.subtitle: Five gentle prompts with illustrations to help kids name their feelings and talk about body kindness.
bodyImage.instruction: Choose a feeling for each picture. You can change your answer anytime.

questions.title: Looking in the mirror
questions.prompt: What feeling comes up when you see a kid smiling kindly at their reflection?
questions.focus: Invite your child to notice strengths, talents, and kindness‚Äînot just appearance.

questions.title: Trying a new sport
questions.prompt: How do you feel seeing someone discovering what their body can do?
questions.focus: Celebrate effort and movement over winning. This builds body confidence.

questions.title: Choosing comfy clothes
questions.prompt: When you see a kid picking clothes that feel right for them, what feeling fits you?
questions.focus: Explain that comfort and self-expression matter more than pleasing others.

questions.title: Drawing a self-portrait
questions.prompt: How do you feel about a child drawing themselves with bright colors?
questions.focus: Encourage creative self-expression and noticing unique traits.

questions.title: Stretch and breathe
questions.prompt: What feeling do you pick seeing someone stretch, breathe, and relax?
questions.focus: Body gratitude grows when kids pair movement with calm breathing.

whatILike.title: What I Like About Me
whatILike.subtitle: A calm space for children to reflect on their strengths, kindness, and growth.
whatILike.saveMessage: Your notes stay on this device so you can come back anytime.

sections.title: Some things I'm good at
sections.hint: Think of skills, games, or hobbies you enjoy practising.

sections.title: Things my friends like about me
sections.hint: Kind words you say, the way you include others, or how you listen.

sections.title: Things I like about me
sections.hint: Maybe your curiosity, humor, patience, or creativity.

sections.title: Things my family love about me
sections.hint: Moments you help out, share, or bring joy to your family.

sections.title: Things that I'm proud of
sections.hint: Times you were brave, kept trying, or learned something new.

sections.title: One unique thing about me
sections.hint: A special interest, talent, perspective, or way you solve problems.

whatILike.encourageDescription: Your child can share if they want, but privacy helps them write freely.

quizzesPage.title: Quizzes
quizzesPage.subtitle: Short, kind quizzes that teach one idea at a time. Try them with your child or let them explore alone.

sleep.title: Sleep & Nutrition Impact
sleep.description: Discover how rest, food, and water support calm moods and steady energy.

questions.question: Using phones or tablets right before bed usually...
options: Makes it harder to fall asleep
questions.correctFeedback: Blue light and exciting content can delay sleep. A short screen break helps the brain slow down.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Screens can wake up the brain. A calming routine helps sleep arrive sooner.

questions.question: Most school-age kids feel best with about...
questions.correctFeedback: About 9-11 hours keeps focus, mood, and growth on track for most kids.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Bodies grow and brains recharge with plenty of night sleep‚Äîusually about 9-11 hours.

questions.question: A gentle bedtime snack could be...
questions.correctFeedback: Light snacks like warm milk or bananas are calming. Sugary or heavy foods can upset sleep.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Try a light, calming snack like warm milk or a banana instead of sugary or heavy foods.

questions.question: Magnesium and vitamin D can help...
options: Keep muscles calm and bones strong
Stop you from ever feeling tired
questions.correctFeedback: These nutrients support relaxed muscles, steady mood, and strong bones. Food first, supplements only if needed.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Magnesium and vitamin D support calm muscles and healthy bones‚Äîfoods like leafy greens and sunlight help.

questions.question: Drinking water through the day helps you...
questions.correctFeedback: Hydration keeps energy, focus, and mood steady. Keep a water bottle nearby.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Sips of water during the day keep your body and brain steady and focused.

summary.good: Great job noticing what helps your body rest.
summary.keepGoing: Nice effort‚Äîtry again to learn even more.

puberty.title: Puberty Basics
puberty.description: Friendly reminders about body changes, feelings, and self-care.

questions.question: Puberty can start at different ages, usually between...
questions.correctFeedback: Bodies have their own clocks. It's okay to start earlier or later than friends.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Most kids begin somewhere around ages 8-14, and every timeline is okay.

questions.question: A common physical change is...
questions.correctFeedback: Growth spurts are normal. Clothes may feel shorter for a while!
questions.incorrectFeedback: Growth spurts happen to many kids during puberty and are normal.

questions.question: Mood swings during puberty are...
options: A sign you are in trouble
questions.correctFeedback: Feelings can be a rollercoaster. Naming emotions and taking breaks can help.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Big feelings are common during puberty. Pausing, breathing, and talking help.

questions.question: A simple way to handle new body smells is...
questions.correctFeedback: Daily washing, fresh clothes, and deodorant can help you feel comfortable.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Fresh clothes, washing, and deodorant help with new body smells.

summary.perfect: You handled every question with confidence!
summary.good: Nice! You know a lot about growing up.
summary.keepGoing: Great start‚Äîtry again to remember even more.

tips.oneAtATime: One question at a time keeps the brain calm and focused.
tips.encouragement: Instant encouragement helps kids try again with confidence.

developmentalChanges.title: Understanding Changes
developmentalChanges.subtitle: Puberty brings many changes to your body and mind. Let's explore them together! üåü

physical.title: Growth Spurts
physical.description: You'll grow taller! This happens at different times for everyone.

physical.title: Body Shape Changes
physical.description: Your body will develop new curves and proportions as you mature.

physical.title: Voice Changes
physical.description: Your voice may deepen or change in pitch - this is totally normal!

physical.title: Skin Changes
physical.description: You might get acne or oily skin. Good hygiene helps manage this.

physical.title: Hair Growth
physical.description: New hair will grow in different places on your body.

physical.title: Body Odor
physical.description: You'll start to sweat more. Using deodorant becomes important!

emotional.title: Mood Swings
emotional.description: Your emotions might feel like a rollercoaster - that's normal!

emotional.title: New Interests
emotional.description: You might develop new hobbies, interests, and passions.

emotional.title: Independence
emotional.description: You'll want more privacy and independence from family.

emotional.title: Relationships
emotional.description: Friendships and social connections become more important.

emotional.title: Self-Awareness
emotional.description: You'll think more about who you are and who you want to be.

emotional.title: Confidence
emotional.description: Building confidence takes time - be patient with yourself!

comics.title: The Growth Spurt
comics.lesson: Growth spurts are a natural part of growing up!

comics.title: Mood Swings
comics.lesson: Mood swings are common during puberty due to hormonal changes.

comics.title: Body Changes
panels: I feel different from my friends
Everyone changes at their own pace!
comics.lesson: Everyone's body changes at different times - that's okay!

quiz.description: Find the silly, colorful quiz adventure on the new Quiz page.

points.label: Timing
points.text: Puberty can start anywhere from ages 8-14. There's no "right" time!

points.label: Pace
points.text: Some changes happen quickly, others take years. Your journey is unique.

points.label: Support
points.text: Talk to trusted adults if you have questions or concerns. They're here to help!

header.title: Understanding Changes & Body Guide
header.subtitle: Learn about physical and emotional changes during puberty üå±

physicalChanges.title: Growth Spurts
physicalChanges.description: You'll grow taller! This happens at different times for everyone.

physicalChanges.title: Body Shape Changes
physicalChanges.description: Your body will develop new curves and proportions as you mature.

physicalChanges.title: Voice Changes
physicalChanges.description: Your voice may deepen or change in pitch - this is totally normal!

physicalChanges.title: Skin Changes
physicalChanges.description: You might get acne or oily skin. Good hygiene helps manage this.

physicalChanges.title: Hair Growth
physicalChanges.description: New hair will grow in different places on your body.

physicalChanges.title: Body Odor
physicalChanges.description: You'll start to sweat more. Using deodorant becomes important!

emotionalChanges.title: Mood Swings
emotionalChanges.description: Your emotions might feel like a rollercoaster - that's normal!

emotionalChanges.title: New Interests
emotionalChanges.description: You might develop new hobbies, interests, and passions.

emotionalChanges.title: Independence
emotionalChanges.description: You'll want more privacy and independence from family.

emotionalChanges.title: Relationships
emotionalChanges.description: Friendships and social connections become more important.

emotionalChanges.title: Self-Awareness
emotionalChanges.description: You'll think more about who you are and who you want to be.

emotionalChanges.title: Confidence
emotionalChanges.description: Building confidence takes time - be patient with yourself!

generalChanges.title: Growth Spurts
generalChanges.description: Most people experience rapid growth during puberty, typically gaining 2-4 inches per year at peak growth.
generalChanges.details: Growth spurts usually last 2-3 years. Hands and feet grow first, followed by arms and legs, and finally the torso. This can make you feel temporarily clumsy - that's completely normal! You might notice your clothes don't fit as well, or you bump into things more often. This is because your body is growing faster than your brain can adjust. Most people reach their adult height by age 18-20, but some continue growing into their early 20s. Remember: everyone grows at their own pace, and there's no "right" height!
tips: Eat nutritious meals to support healthy growth
Get plenty of sleep (8-10 hours) - growth happens during rest
Stay active with sports or exercise
Be patient - growth spurts are temporary

generalChanges.title: Skin Changes
generalChanges.description: Your skin produces more oil, which can lead to acne on your face, chest, and back.
generalChanges.details: Wash your face twice daily with a gentle cleanser. Acne is normal and temporary. If it bothers you, talk to a doctor about treatments. Never pop pimples as it can cause scarring! Hormonal changes increase oil production, which can clog pores. Acne is most common on the face, but can also appear on the chest, back, and shoulders. Most people experience some acne during puberty, and it usually improves by the late teens or early 20s. If acne is severe or causing emotional distress, a dermatologist can help with treatment options.
tips: Wash face morning and night with gentle, oil-free cleanser
Avoid touching your face with dirty hands
Use non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) moisturizers
Change pillowcases regularly
Don't scrub too hard - gentle is better
See a doctor if acne is severe or painful

generalChanges.title: Sweating & Body Odor
generalChanges.description: You'll start sweating more, especially from underarms, and develop a stronger body odor.
generalChanges.details: Daily showers become important! Use deodorant or antiperspirant. Wear clean clothes and breathable fabrics. This is your body maturing - everyone goes through it! Sweat glands become more active during puberty, especially in the armpits, feet, and groin area. Body odor happens when bacteria on your skin break down sweat. This is completely normal and part of growing up. Good hygiene habits will help you feel fresh and confident.
tips: Shower or bathe daily, especially after exercise
Use deodorant or antiperspirant every day
Wear clean clothes - change daily
Choose breathable fabrics like cotton
Keep extra deodorant in your school bag
Wash underarms thoroughly with soap

generalChanges.title: Body Hair Growth
generalChanges.description: Hair will grow in new places including underarms, legs, and pubic area.
generalChanges.details: The amount and thickness varies greatly between people. Some have lots of body hair, others have very little - both are completely normal! You can choose to remove it or not - it's your choice. Body hair typically starts appearing around ages 9-14, but timing varies. Hair may grow on legs, underarms, pubic area, and sometimes on the chest, back, or face. The color and texture of body hair may be different from the hair on your head. Whether to remove body hair is a personal choice - there's no right or wrong answer.
tips: Body hair is natural and normal
Removing hair is optional - your choice
If removing hair, learn safe methods from trusted adults
Shaving requires proper technique to avoid cuts
Waxing and other methods have pros and cons
Remember: everyone's body hair is different

generalChanges.title: Weight & Body Shape Changes
generalChanges.description: Your body composition changes - you may gain weight as you grow taller and develop muscle.
generalChanges.details: Weight gain during puberty is normal and healthy! Your body needs extra calories to support growth. You might notice your body shape changing - this is part of normal development. Focus on healthy habits rather than a specific number on the scale. Your body is preparing for adulthood, and these changes are necessary for healthy development.
tips: Weight gain during puberty is normal and healthy
Focus on nutritious foods, not dieting
Stay active with activities you enjoy
Your body shape is unique - embrace it
Talk to a doctor if you have concerns about weight
Avoid comparing your body to others

generalChanges.title: Sleep Patterns Change
generalChanges.description: You might need more sleep, or your sleep schedule might shift later.
generalChanges.details: During puberty, your body's internal clock shifts, making you feel more awake at night and sleepy in the morning. This is why many teenagers are "night owls." However, you still need 8-10 hours of sleep for healthy growth and development. Try to maintain a consistent sleep schedule, even on weekends.
tips: Aim for 8-10 hours of sleep each night
Try to go to bed and wake up at similar times
Avoid screens 30-60 minutes before bed
Create a relaxing bedtime routine
Keep your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet
Limit caffeine, especially in the afternoon

femaleChanges.title: Breast Development
femaleChanges.description: Breasts begin to develop, starting with small buds that may feel tender.
femaleChanges.details: Development can take 4-5 years to complete. It's normal for breasts to be different sizes or develop at different rates. Many people need a training bra around this time. Tenderness is normal! Breast development typically starts between ages 8-13, but can begin earlier or later. You might notice small, firm lumps under the nipples first - these are called breast buds. One breast might develop faster than the other - this is completely normal and they usually even out over time. Soreness or tenderness is common and usually temporary.
tips: Breast development happens in stages over several years
It's normal for one breast to be slightly larger
Tenderness usually goes away as development continues
A soft, supportive bra can help with comfort
Talk to a trusted adult if you have questions
All breast sizes are normal and beautiful

femaleChanges.title: Hip Widening & Body Shape
femaleChanges.description: Hips and thighs become wider and more rounded.
femaleChanges.details: This is caused by hormones preparing your body for adulthood. Your body shape will change from straight to more curved. Remember: bodies come in all shapes and sizes! As estrogen levels increase, fat is distributed to the hips, thighs, and buttocks, creating a more curved figure. This typically happens gradually over several years. Your waist might become more defined, and your overall body shape will become more adult-like. These changes are natural and healthy.
tips: Body shape changes are normal and healthy
Everyone develops at their own pace
Embrace your unique body shape
Wear clothes that make you feel comfortable
Focus on health, not appearance
Remember: all body shapes are beautiful

femaleChanges.title: Menstruation (Periods)
femaleChanges.description: Monthly menstrual cycles begin, typically between ages 11-14.
femaleChanges.details: Your first period might be irregular - that's normal! Use pads, tampons, or menstrual cups. Track your cycle to know when to expect it. Cramps are common and can be managed with heat, rest, and pain relief if needed. Periods usually start 1-2 years after breast development begins. The first few periods may be irregular - cycles can range from 21-45 days and still be normal. Periods typically last 3-7 days. It's helpful to track your cycle to understand your body's pattern.
tips: Keep period supplies (pads/tampons) in your bag
Track your cycle with an app or calendar
For cramps: try heat, gentle exercise, or pain relief
Change pads/tampons every 4-6 hours
It's normal for early periods to be irregular
Talk to a doctor if periods are very painful or heavy
Remember: periods are a sign of a healthy body

femaleChanges.title: Vaginal Discharge
femaleChanges.description: Clear or whitish discharge is normal and keeps the vagina healthy.
femaleChanges.details: This usually starts before your first period. It's your body's way of keeping itself clean. If discharge has a strong odor or causes itching, talk to a doctor. Vaginal discharge is a normal part of the menstrual cycle. It helps keep the vagina clean and prevents infection. The amount, color, and consistency can change throughout the month. Normal discharge is usually clear or white, and doesn't have a strong smell.
tips: Normal discharge is clear or white
It may increase around ovulation (mid-cycle)
Wear breathable cotton underwear
Avoid douching - it's not necessary
See a doctor if discharge has strong odor, unusual color, or causes itching
This is your body's natural cleaning system

femaleChanges.title: Emotional Changes (Female)
femaleChanges.description: Hormonal changes can affect your emotions and mood.
femaleChanges.details: Estrogen and progesterone levels fluctuate during your menstrual cycle, which can affect how you feel. You might experience mood swings, especially before your period (PMS - Premenstrual Syndrome). This is completely normal. Some people feel more emotional, irritable, or sensitive at certain times of the month. These feelings are valid and temporary.
tips: Mood changes are normal and temporary
Track your cycle to understand patterns
Practice self-care during difficult days
Talk to someone you trust about your feelings
Gentle exercise can help improve mood
See a doctor if mood changes are severe

maleChanges.title: Voice Deepening
maleChanges.description: Your voice will gradually become deeper as your voice box (larynx) grows.
maleChanges.details: Voice "cracking" during this time is normal and temporary! The Adam's apple (visible bump in throat) becomes more prominent. The voice change process usually takes several months to a year. This typically happens between ages 12-16. Your voice might crack or sound hoarse as it adjusts. This happens because your vocal cords are growing longer and thicker. The change is gradual, and eventually your voice will stabilize at a deeper pitch. This is a normal part of becoming a man.
tips: Voice cracking is temporary and normal
The change happens gradually over months
Your voice will eventually stabilize
Don't worry if it sounds different - everyone goes through this
Practice speaking to get used to your new voice
If voice changes are concerning, talk to a doctor

maleChanges.title: Facial Hair Growth
maleChanges.description: Hair begins growing on the upper lip, chin, and cheeks.
maleChanges.details: It starts as light fuzz and gradually becomes thicker. You'll eventually need to start shaving if you choose to. Ask a trusted adult to teach you how to shave safely when you're ready. Facial hair typically starts appearing around ages 13-16, but timing varies. It usually starts as light, soft hair on the upper lip, then spreads to the chin, cheeks, and neck. The amount and thickness of facial hair varies greatly - some people have thick beards, others have very little hair. Both are normal!
tips: Facial hair growth varies - everyone is different
Start with light fuzz before it becomes thick
Learn proper shaving technique from a trusted adult
Use shaving cream and a sharp razor
Shave in the direction of hair growth to avoid irritation
It's okay to wait until you're ready to start shaving

maleChanges.title: Muscle Development
maleChanges.description: Shoulders broaden and muscles become more defined.
maleChanges.details: You'll naturally become stronger as testosterone increases. Upper body strength especially increases. Regular exercise helps build healthy muscles, but avoid overdoing it! During puberty, muscle mass increases naturally due to hormonal changes. Your shoulders will get broader, and you'll develop more muscle definition. This happens gradually over several years. Regular exercise supports healthy muscle development, but it's important not to overdo it or use weights that are too heavy for your age.
tips: Muscle development happens naturally with hormones
Regular exercise supports healthy growth
Focus on proper form, not heavy weights
Include rest days in your exercise routine
Eat nutritious foods to support muscle growth
Talk to a coach or trainer for safe exercise guidance

maleChanges.title: Genital Changes
maleChanges.description: The penis and testicles grow larger. Erections become more frequent.
maleChanges.details: Random erections are completely normal and not always related to sexual thoughts. "Wet dreams" (nocturnal emissions) are also normal. These are signs of healthy development. Genital development typically begins around ages 10-14. The penis and testicles grow larger, and the scrotum (the sac holding the testicles) becomes darker and larger. Random erections can happen at any time and are not always related to sexual thoughts - they're a normal part of development. "Wet dreams" occur when the body releases semen during sleep - this is also completely normal.
tips: Genital changes are normal and healthy
Random erections are not always related to thoughts
"Wet dreams" are normal and nothing to be ashamed of
Everyone develops at their own pace
If you have questions, talk to a trusted adult or doctor
These changes are signs of healthy development

maleChanges.title: Emotional Changes (Male)
maleChanges.description: Hormonal changes can affect your emotions and mood.
maleChanges.details: Testosterone levels increase during puberty, which can affect your emotions. You might feel more aggressive, competitive, or have stronger emotional reactions. You might also experience mood swings. These emotional changes are normal and part of growing up. Learning to manage emotions is an important life skill.
tips: Emotional changes are normal during puberty
Find healthy ways to express emotions (sports, art, music)
Talk to someone you trust about your feelings
Practice deep breathing when feeling overwhelmed
Exercise can help manage strong emotions
Remember: it's okay to have feelings and express them

comics.title: The Growth Spurt
comics.lesson: Growth spurts are a natural part of growing up!

comics.title: Mood Swings
comics.lesson: Mood swings are common during puberty due to hormonal changes.

panels.text: I feel different from my friends
Everyone changes at their own pace!

comics.lesson: Everyone's body changes at different times - that's okay!

points.title: Timing
points.text: Puberty can start anywhere from ages 8-14. There's no "right" time!

points.title: Pace
points.text: Some changes happen quickly, others take years. Your journey is unique.

points.title: Support
points.text: Talk to trusted adults if you have questions or concerns. They're here to help!
